annotation.TEXT: Similar to Revenge of the Fallen, this game has secret power-up's in each of its main stages. There's also a few extra items in the form of books, which add entries to the "Collection" option on the start menu.

Every stage in this game has some kind of mid-boss, with a few of them being Robot Masters from the official series. Out of all of them, Napalm Man is the only one who fights like his original version. Even then, he suffers from the same trait that all the mid-bosses have: They completely lack post-hit invincibility.
For the record: No, there's no indication that there's a hidden path there. You'd have to essentially make a mental map of the level and figure it out from there.

Nearly all of the bosses in this game are incredibly easy, to the point where it's not really worth talking about any of them (save for a select few). Illuminati is a slight exception, mostly because this fight can end up being easy or hard depending on what random attack he does.

Also, yes, Milk is the weapon capable of breaking open most of the walls in this game. With that aside, it's still not that useful in most situations, outside of using it as a utility for bypassing things. That is of course, unless you're facing off against something with an unfortunate weakness affiliation to it.

This level's main gimmick revolves around items that effect your health bar. The gray/white items cause you to slowly lose health over time, unless you dive into a pool of milk (which will slowly regenerate your health). Picking up a pink/white item will revert your status back to normal.

Time for the run-down on the basic mechanics: Mega Man controls about how you'd expect him to (chargeable buster, sliding, etc). Interestingly, you start with an exit ability that lets you warp out of stages, however it works a bit differently than you might expect. The exit unit actually has its own energy bar, which can be filled by red power-up items. I'll state this right now: I never had a use for the exit ability or even filled its meter up during my casual playthroughs (unless I intentionally went back into stages just to fill it up).

Milk Spray sends out a huge spread shot of projectiles that you can continually fire by holding down the button. It's decent for taking out hordes of small enemies, but it doesn't work so well against larger ones on account of its very low damage output (the projectiles themselves are actually weaker than a single buster pellet).

My main reason for coming to this stage was to get the Air Break item, considering Burning Coal is pretty useless for the most part. Despite having decent damage output, its trajectory is so limited that you'd basically have to spam it to hit your target. Aside from weakness affiliations (mainly, Sheep Man), it's not going to be seeing a lot of action here.

Illuminati Tape is basically a faster, better version of Spark Shock. Almost everything hit by it is locked in place, allowing you to bypass it without taking contact damage. It also works on enemy projectiles as well (which can actually be a bad thing sometimes, since they can block out potential shots aimed at the enemies themselves).

Sometimes, there's a few instances where my usual introductions on things aren't that necessary - mainly when the intro of the game says more about it than I ever could. Today's game is one such case...

One of the nice things about this game is that you can jump up and through the bottom of the yoku blocks. This gimmick is used on a few other platforms in some stages, but for the most part, you'll mainly see it with the yoku blocks.
The only thing worth noting about Thomas is that he doesn't deal any contact damage (likely due to his size). Beyond that, he's just as easy as a majority of the bosses in this game.

Pencil Bomb seems like it should do more damage than it actually does (considering the huge explosion it produces). Even though it only deals moderate damage, it's still pretty decent for said radius on the explosion, which also lets it bypass some forms of shielded enemies.

In case it wasn't evident before, this game can be really glitchty at times. As a testament to this, Milk apparently froze up for a moment during this fight. I'm not sure if this can happen to the other bosses, but in this case, it thankfully didn't soft lock the game.

So then, as obvious as it should be by now, "Mega Man: Square Root of Negative One" is a straight up joke game. From my experience, a majority of these types of games tend to be one-off experiences in the form of a single stage. This one however, is actually a full game.
